Project Description  The Project is to (i) reconstruct and improve the Andkhoy-Qaisar 
section  (210  kilometers)  of  the  national  primary  ring  road,  (ii) 
install toll facilities including toll plazas and weighing machines for 
newly improved primary roads in Afghanistan, and (iii) provide 
project  management  support  to  the  Ministry  of  Public  Works 
(MPW).  
   
Rationale  Much of Afghanistan’s road infrastructure has been destroyed or 
damaged in more than two decades of conflict. Damaged roads 
became  bottlenecks  to  the  movement  of  people  and  goods. 
Restricted  movement  has  aggravated  the  division  and 
disintegration of the country, as travel time and vehicle operating 
cost on roads significantly increased. The result is a virtual loss of 
efficient means of transport connecting Kabul to regional centers, 
and regional centers to remote villages. 
 
The Andkhoy-Qaisar road forms part of the Herat-Andkhoy road, 
which is the last unpaved section of the national primary ring road. 
The project area is one of the least developed areas that the ring 
road  touches.  Due  to  its  remoteness  and  extreme  weather  in 
winter and summer, the project area is still in need of continued 
humanitarian  aid  and  assistance  in  basic  social  services. 
Improvement to the road will facilitate provision of such services.  
 
The  Project  is  part  of  coordinated  international  assistance  to 
improve the road connecting Herat to Andkhoy, which will become 
a  major  north-south  link  across  the  central  mountains,  and 
significantly improve the stability and reliability of the transport 
system  in  Afghanistan.  The  improved  road  will  also  change 
transport in the subregion. Together with the international links 
currently being improved to the Central Asian republics, Iran, and 
Pakistan, the road will form a major road transport corridor from 
Central Asia to the warm water ports in the south. This will reduce 
transport costs, and contribute to economic growth and poverty 
reduction in the subregion.

The Project, with other funding agencies’ support to improve road

The Project will also contribute to increased social stability as the

Risks and Assumptions  The risks to the Project are related to (i) the overall political and

roads, (iii) the Government’s weak implementation capacity, and 
(iv) timely provision of counterpart resources. 
 
The risks will be mitigated through (i) continued close monitoring

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Islamic  Republic  of  Afghanistan  for  the  Andkhoy-Qaisar  Road  Project.  The  project 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  Afghanistan is a landlocked country. With a large area (about 652,000 square kilometers 
[km2]) and an estimated population of 22.8 million widely spread across the largely mountainous 
terrain, roads are the principal means of transport.1 Its road network comprises about 6,100 km 
of national roads and 15,000 km of provincial roads. Of the national roads, 3,300 km are 
national primary roads including 2,400 km that were originally paved. The national primary road 
network consists largely of the 2,300 km ring road that connects Afghanistan’s major regional 
centers (Herat, Kandahar, Mazar-e-Sharif, Maimana, and Sheberghan) with Kabul, and the 
roads linking to neighboring countries.2 The remaining 2,800 km of national roads are secondary 
roads with gravel or earthen surface. The 15,000 km of provincial roads are gravel or earthen 
and comprise 5,400 km of provincial primary roads and 9,600 km of provincial secondary roads. 
A tertiary road network consists of rural roads3 and substantial lengths of urban roads.4  
 
3.  Much of Afghanistan’s road infrastructure was destroyed or damaged during the more 
than two decades of conflict. Lack of resources and capacity prevented maintenance, and has 
led to major deterioration and loss of infrastructure. The effects of military actions are more 
pronounced—damaged bridges and tunnels have become bottlenecks to the movement of 
people and goods. Restricted movement has aggravated the division and disintegration of the 
country, as travel time and vehicle operating cost on roads significantly increased.5 
 
4.  A comprehensive needs assessment of the Afghanistan transport sector, during March-
May 2002 by major external funding agencies including the Asian Development Bank (ADB), 
revealed that 54% of national roads are in poor condition, 26% in fair condition, and only 20% in 
good condition. It urged the entire primary road network be rehabilitated on a priority basis.6 
  
5.  Afghanistan’s road network is characterized by very low road density. The road density 
of 0.03 km per km2 is far lower than that of the Kyrgyz Republic and Tajikistan, which also have 
largely  mountainous  terrain  and  similar  population  density,  and  even  lower  than  that  of 
Balochistan in Pakistan, where population density is about half that of Afghanistan.7 Even 
without  the  damage  inflicted  during  the  conflict  period,  Afghanistan’s  road  network  needs 
substantial improvement to provide basic connectivity available elsewhere in the subregion.

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Overview of Reconstruction and Economic Situation 
8.  The result of the more than two decades of conflict and civil strife is utter devastation of 
the economy and infrastructure, coupled with ravaged social, political, and ethnic fabric. The 
reconstruction of Afghanistan was a daunting task for the transitional Government installed in 
2002. The Government has made significant progress on many fronts. The adoption of a new 
constitution in January 2004 designating Afghanistan as an Islamic republic and including a 
strong centralized presidency, a bicameral legislature, and gender equality in principle; the 
approval of an electoral law in May 2004; the presidential elections under universal suffrage in 
October 2004; and the prospect of parliamentary elections in April 2005 constitute a strong 
framework for recovery and development. The Government has demonstrated its commitment 
to political, economic, and social reform, and to developing a free and competitive economic 
system and private sector-driven growth. It has shown strong ownership of the reconstruction 
effort, working closely with development agencies to rebuild critical physical infrastructure and to 
reorient Soviet-style public sector institutions to promote market-led development.  
 
9.  The private sector responded favorably to the Government’s efforts. The International 
Monetary Fund estimates that real gross domestic product, excluding opium production, grew 
by about 30% in 2002/03 and 23% in 2003/04. The growth resulted from recovered agricultural 
production  after  years  of  drought,  an  urban  construction  boom,  and  increased  service 
establishments driven by the international community’s spending and emergency assistance 
efforts. Continued strong growth in agriculture, services, and construction is expected in 2004. 
 
2.  Government Strategy and External Assistance 
10.  The transitional Government declared that reconstruction and rehabilitation of the road 
system, especially of national primary roads, is the country’s top priority in reconstruction. Since 
2002, with external assistance, the Government has been making massive efforts to reestablish 
the road network, in order to facilitate provision of basic social services to remote provinces, to 
provide security, and to involve all the population in undertaking nation-building activities.  
 
11.  The national primary roads are being rehabilitated with financial and technical assistance 
(TA) from bilateral and multilateral funding agencies. ADB is financing rehabilitation of the road 
from Pul-e Khumri via Mazar-e Sharif to Andkhoy under the $150 million loan for the Emergency

12.  Although the primary road network touches most of the major population centers, a 
single road often connects one population center to another and to the nearest regional center, 
and a regional center to Kabul. Failure of a single road link will have severe impacts not only on 
the population that it directly serves but also on the population in other parts of the country. A 
pronounced  example  is  the  Salang  tunnel—the  only  reliable  transport  connection  between 
Kabul and the northern provinces. Closure of the Salang tunnel virtually cuts the connection 
between the north and the south of the country. This vulnerability and lack of redundancy in the 
transport system often exacerbated the division of the country during the conflict period. To 
become an effective state with central Government authority across the country, connectivity 
must be improved to places and people and thereby integrate all parts of the country. Improving 
the road network, and in particular strengthening the primary road network, will continue to be 
the Government’s top priority. Given the country’s resource constraints, continued assistance by 
the international community will be needed to establish a reliable and robust transport system. 
 
13.  The Government’s weak capability to mobilize its own financial resources has been a 
major constraint for reconstruction of Afghanistan. For the fiscal year 2003/04, the central 
Government relied on customs duties for 40% of its domestic revenue. This share could have 
been much higher if the central Government had full access to the duties and charges being 
collected at border provinces. Provincial governments still exert influence over  border and 
customs  procedures.  Inadequate  infrastructure  and  outdated  cumbersome  procedures  are 
causing enormous delays in moving things across the border. Lack of proper control and 
oversight has resulted in corruption, smuggling, and other illegal activities. To counter these 
problems and broaden the revenue base, the Government prepared a 5-year plan to reform and 
modernize customs, and is vigorously implementing the plan with assistance from the World 
Bank and other funding agencies. The Government expects customs revenue, and hence its 
financial  position  to  improve  as  primary  roads  forming  part  of  major  subregional  transport 
corridors  are  upgraded.  Thus  improvement  of  primary  roads  is  a  strategic  focus  of  the 
Government.

3.  Capacity Building and Sector Reform 
15.  To counter the lack of capacity in line ministries to plan and prepare projects, the 
Government  established  a  dedicated  agency,  the  Afghanistan  Assistance  Coordination 
Authority,  to  handle  planning,  coordination,  preparation,  and  procurement  of  major 
reconstruction projects. The authority was later reorganized into the Afghanistan Reconstruction 
and Development Services (ARDS). ARDS’s Procurement Unit handles procurement for most 
externally financed projects. For project implementation, the comprehensive needs assessment 
recommended provision of assistance to MPW through a team of international and capable 
domestic experts to compensate for the lack of capacity to implement large-scale projects. 
Under the ongoing TA cluster for Capacity Building for Reconstruction and Development,15 ADB 
is providing assistance to MPW for project planning and management. Under the EIRRP, the 
project implementation unit established within MPW is coordinating with ARDS and gradually 
building capacity to handle day-to-day project implementation. Several MPW staff have been 
attached to the contractor and the supervision consultants under the EIRRP to receive on-the-

(v) improving transparency and accountability, (vi) instituting a mechanism for cost recovery, 
(vii) encouraging private sector participation, and (viii) establishing a system for national road

4.  Subregional Cooperation for Transport Corridor Development 
18.  The efforts by Afghanistan to rehabilitate and reconstruct its shattered road network 
have  drawn  much  attention  of  the  neighboring  countries.  An  improved  road  network  in 
Afghanistan will result in an improved transport network in the subregion. Landlocked Central 
Asian  republics  have  shown  a  great  interest  in  establishing  transport  corridors  through 
Afghanistan to warm-water ports on the Arabian Sea and the Gulf. Iran and Pakistan are rapidly 
developing their ports and improving roads connecting to the ports in expectation of increased 
import/export and transit shipment of goods through their ports.

5.  Security Situation 
21.  Although the recent developments in reconstruction, notably the successful presidential 
election, are encouraging, the country still faces several problems that could undermine the 
progress and hamper development. In a recent report of the United Nations (UN) secretary 
general to the UN Security Council, extremist violence, factionalism, and the narcotics industry 
are highlighted as threats to the consolidation of peace and stability in Afghanistan.23 On these 
fronts, the Government has made significant achievements in the past 2 years. They include 
inauguration of the Afghan National Army and national police force; commencement of major 
reform in the Ministry of Defense; initial implementation of a disarmament, demobilization, and 
reintegration program; formulation of a national drug control strategy; and steady progress in 
removing land mines. The internationally sponsored security arrangements for Kabul, based on 
the International Security Assistance Forces in cooperation with Afghan security forces, have 
worked  reasonably  well.  Security  on  the  main  intercity  roads  has  improved  significantly 
compared with the situation 2 years ago.  
 
22.  However, the security situation outside Kabul still largely depends on a delicate power 
balance between local warlords and the central Government in Kabul. In the country’s southern, 
southeastern,  and  eastern  provinces,  activity  of  international  development  agencies  and 
nongovernment  organizations  has  been  disrupted  by  the  revival  of  Taliban  elements.  The 
Government has been making every effort to curtail the influence of the warlords and factional 
leaders  in  the  reconstruction  activity.  The  disarmament,  demobilization,  and  reintegration 
program is the key instrument to reduce the number and size of private militias and undercut the 
military strength of the regional governors. Progress has been slow. By the end of July 2004, 
only a little over 12% of the militia forces are estimated to have turned in their weapons. In the 
political arena, the Government has made some gain in decreasing the influence of warlords 
and factional leaders by both inclusive and confrontational measures. The central Government 
banned local warlords from assuming political and military posts in a provincial government, and 
offered them posts in the central Government. Some warlords accepted the offer. Vacated posts 
in the provincial governments were filled with officials from Kabul. Still in many parts of the 
country, quasi-autonomy continues to exist under the rule of local leaders with different scales. 
They  collect  taxes  and  customs  duties  in  the  case  of  border  provinces  and  support  their 
operations. This significantly reduces the central Government’s ability to collect revenues to 
provide for basic central government functions. This situation enables regional warlords to 
maintain their military strength and keep their influence over regional politics far off from the 
central Government. This leads to fragile security over the country. The security situation will 
continue to constrain the progress of reconstruction, and security concerns may continue to 
discourage foreign and large-scale domestic investment.

6.  Opium-Related Problems 
24.  Afghanistan is the world’s largest producer of illicit opium. The current ban on cultivation 
has had an extremely limited effect. Opium is a major source of cash income for farmers 
because of its ready profitability, and their lack of other livelihood alternatives. According to the 
UN Office on Drugs and Crime, opium was cultivated on 80,000 hectares in 2003, an increase 
of 8% over 2002, and production increased by 6% to 3,600 tons, 20 times more than in 2001, 
the last year of Taliban rule. Farmers grew poppies in 28 of the country’s 32 provinces in 2003, 
up from 18 in 1999. About 264,000 families, or about 7% of Afghanistan’s population, are 
estimated to be producing poppies, each cultivating an average of 0.3 hectares. The UN Office 
on Drugs and Crime estimates average yearly earnings at $3,900 per opium-growing family, or 
$594 per capita, in a country where per capita gross domestic product is only $207.25 The share 
of  poppy  production  in  the  economy  is  large.  If  opium  exports  were  included,  total  gross 
domestic product would be 40% greater.  
 
25.  Poppy  cultivation,  and  narcotics  production  and  trade  constitute  a  major  threat  to 
Afghanistan’s security and political normalization, and tie the poor rural population to regional 
warlords and international crime syndicates. To combat this problem, the Government has 
developed a national counternarcotics strategy, and is working with aid agencies involved in the 
security sector to contain and eradicate poppy cultivation and provide support for alternative 
livelihoods. ADB support focuses on helping farm households develop livelihood alternatives to 
poppy cultivation. ADB activities include creating an enabling environment for commercializing 
and diversifying agricultural production, and rehabilitating irrigation systems. ADB is using a 
demand-driven,  participatory,  and  community-based  approach.  ADB,  through  some  of  its 
subregional activities, is supporting measures to contain the flow of narcotics across borders. 
These include building capacity and strengthening customs and immigration departments in the 
region. Under the Central And South Asia Transport And Trade Forum, Afghanistan and its 
neighboring countries are discussing ways to contain drug trafficking across borders.

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
46.  The Andkhoy-Qaisar road is one of the last unpaved sections of the national primary 
road network. The Project will dramatically decrease the vehicle operating costs and passenger 
time on the project road. The primary beneficiaries will be the residents in the project area, 
estimated at about 800,000 and mostly engaged in agriculture; 50% live under the poverty line. 
The residents will benefit from improved access to health, education, and other social services. 
Benefits will also arise from the increased prices of agricultural products, for which the project 
area is endowed with a significant resource base. The project road will form part of the second 
paved road corridor linking the north and south of the country across the central mountains, will 
add to the country’s road network, and significantly improve the reliability of road transport. 
Increased trade and transit through the improved transport corridor from Central Asia through 
Afghanistan to Iran and Pakistan, including the project road, will benefit a broad range of 
population including consumers, manufacturers, and transport operators who will directly or 
indirectly use goods and services transported on the project road 
 
A.  Social Impacts 
47.  The prolonged war in the country exacerbated by drought has severely affected the 
livelihoods of the local population. About 53% of the population are classified as poor and live 
on  less  than  $1  a  day  (footnote  14).  Decline  in  farm  productivity  and  loss  of  seasonal 
opportunities for agriculture labor are the main determinants of poverty. An estimate of poverty 
incidence through proxy measures in the project influence area indicates that about 35–50% 
households are poor, and among the poor households 50–80% live in absolute poverty. The 
average monthly income of the poor households was as low as AF3,700. Most villages in the 
project influence area lack primary health care facilities or are located at least 10 km away from 
the nearest basic health care clinic. Due to the absence of primary health care facilities coupled

13
with poor condition of roads and lack of transportation facilities, the mortality rate was observed 
to be high among women and children from simple complications of childbirth, lack of proper 
immunization, and preventable childhood illnesses.  
 
48.  The direct poverty impact would be from income generation and demand for unskilled 
labor  resulting  directly  from  road  construction.  The  improved  road  will  significantly  reduce 
transport cost and travel time. This will translate into improved access to schools, medical 
clinics, and employment centers. The improved road will decrease the chances of accident 
deaths and disabilities that have resulted from extremely poor road conditions. The poverty 
impact ratio (0.69) indicates that the poor will receive a high proportion of these benefits. The 
indirect, but important impact will be the growth of local trade and production activities, and 
reduced  prices  of  commodities  facilitated  by  improved  access  to  local,  national,  and 
international markets. The road improvement is also expected to mainstream local economies 
with the overall national economy, and facilitate exploitation of available natural resources, such 
as minerals, gas, and other resources. These benefits are expected to significantly increase 
household incomes and quality of life, and reduce the overall poverty incidence. The economic 
assessment and distributional analysis are provided in Supplementary Appendix A. 
  
49.  Incidence of poverty among women is higher than among men and is characterized by 
low  endowment  of  land  and  productive  assets,  unemployment,  discrimination  in  the  labor 
market, and limited access to economic options and political processes. Women in Afghanistan 
are generally denied inheritance rights, adequate food and nutrition, choice of education, and 
participation in the decision-making process of household economic activities. In the project 
area, the level of attainment in elementary education ranges between 12–36% for women and is 
much  lower  than  that  for  men,  which  ranges  between  62–77%.  However,  with  the  recent 
appreciation for education for women and changing socioeconomic realities, especially due to 
the increased number of households headed by women, consequent to loss of male members, 
the involvement of women in economic activities is slowly beginning to be acceptable. Although 
women will not benefit from direct employment opportunities to be provided under the Project, 
they  will  benefit  from  reduced  travel  times  and  transport  costs.  With  the  improved  road, 
combined with increased availability of transport services, women will find it easier to reach 
schools, clinics, hospitals, other market centers, and district and provincial capitals.  
 
50.  While  the  project  area  is  ethnically  heterogeneous,  different  ethnic  groups  are 
segregated by functions, and sometimes by district. The social assessment did not identify the 
presence of any indigenous population.  
 
51.  Afghanistan  is  considered  to  have  a  low  prevalence  of  human  immunodeficiency 
virus/acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (HIV/AIDS) prevalence but to be at high risk for 
spread of HIV infection. The reasons behind this include (i) over two decades of protracted 
armed conflicts, (ii) low sociopolitical and economic status of women, (iii) huge numbers of 
people displaced internally and externally, (iv) the extremely poor social and public health 
infrastructure, (v) drug trafficking, (vi) use of injecting drugs, and (vii) lack of blood safety 
practices. Only 11 cases of HIV have been reported to the World Health Organization for 
Afghanistan, although many more cases may be undetected and unreported.  
 
52.  Nongovernment organizations and UN agencies, such as the United Nations Children’s 
Fund  and  the  World  Health  Organization,  are  already  active  in  the  area  of  HIV/AIDS  in 
Afghanistan. The Government is working on the National Plan of Action against HIV/AIDS and 
Sexually Transmitted Diseases. The national program (2004–2010) focuses on surveillance and 
research;  prevention  of  HIV/AIDS  through  information,  education  and  communication  and

behavioral  change  communication;  prevention  and  effective  management  of  sexually

B.  Economic Assessment 
54.  The economic assessment (Appendix 12) was conducted for the entire stretch of the 
Herat-Andkhoy  road  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Guidelines  for  the  Economic  Analysis  of 
Projects. The highway design and maintenance model (HDM4) was used to calculate vehicle 
operating costs and time costs with modification for conditions in Afghanistan. The major inputs 
include vehicle characteristics and related costs, and construction and maintenance costs. The 
major benefits are derived from savings of vehicle operating costs and travel time due to 
rehabilitation of the project road, which will provide a stimulus for economic growth in the project 
area. The time required for traveling from Andkhoy to Qaisar is currently more than 8 hours. The 
Project will reduce this to 2.5 hours. The travel time on the entire Herat-Andkhoy road is 
currently more than 24 hours with an average travel speed of slightly more than 20 km/hour. 
Together with the planned improvement to other road sections of the Herat-Andkhoy road, the 
Project will contribute to significant reduction in travel time and cost, turning the painful road trip 
along the Herat-Andkhoy road into a safe single-day daylight trip. 
 
55.  The current traffic level is low due to the very poor condition of the road and the overall 
reduced economic activity due to many years of war and the recent severe draught. Considering 
that a strong economic recovery is anticipated in the short term, a high level of generated and 
induced traffic is expected. Based on this development prospect, the generated and induced 
traffic was estimated in absolute numbers assuming expected growth of outputs and activities 
and trip rates, considered to be realized 3 years after the project road becomes operational. 
 
56.  An economic evaluation resulted in an economic internal rate of return of 19.1% for the 
overall project road. The project road was evaluated up to and including 2027, providing a 
benefit period of 20 years; a residual value of 10% was applied in 2027. The traffic estimate is 
still conservative, as it does not include international transit traffic from the three neighboring 
countries (Iran, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan) adjacent to the northwest region.

D.  Risks 
58.  Implementation of the Project entails a number of risks: 
 
(i)  The overall political and security situation remains volatile. ADB will need to 
closely monitor the situation and coordinate with local and central authorities and 
the UN to ensure adequate protection.30 ADB’s TA for the Security of ADB-
Financed Projects in Afghanistan will provide advice on how to ensure a safe 
work  environment  for  on-site  personnel  assigned  by  the  contractors, 
subcontractors, and consulting firms. Under the prevailing conditions, however, 
this  security  risk  cannot  be  mitigated  completely,  and  delays  in  project 
implementation, if security hazards occur in project locations, will be inevitable 
despite measures put in place to control the risk. 
 
(ii)  The regional warlords and militia leaders maintain their military strength and their 
influence in regional politics. This political instability could hamper smooth supply 
of  raw  materials  and  equipment,  which  would  be  transported  through  areas 
controlled by regional warlords and militia leaders, and constrain supervision of 
construction works by the consultants and ADB staff.   
 
(iii)  Improved roads can be used as a route to transport opium. The Government will

ROAD SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.   Road Network 
 
1.  Afghanistan’s road network comprises about 6,100 kilometers (km) of national roads and 
15,000 km of provincial roads. Of the national roads, 3,300 km are national primary roads 
including 2,400 km that were originally paved. The national primary road network consists 
largely of the 2,300 km ring road that connects Afghanistan’s major regional centers (Herat, 
Kandahar, Mazar-e-Sharif, Maimana, and Sheberghan) with Kabul, and the roads linking to 
neighboring countries including Iran, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan. The 
remaining 2,800 km of national roads are secondary roads with either gravel or earthen surface. 
The 15,000 km of provincial roads are gravel or earthen, and categorized into 5,400 km of 
provincial primary roads and 9,600 km of provincial secondary roads. The tertiary road network 
consists of rural roads that are roughly estimated to be 15,000–20,000 km, and substantial 
lengths of urban roads roughly estimated to be 3,000 km including 1,060 km in Kabul. 
 
2.  Most of the national primary road network was improved to the paved standard before 
the  conflict,  mainly  with  external  assistance.  The  ring-road  section  from  Jawzjan-Faryab 
province border to Herat (575 km) was left unpaved due to the outbreak of civil conflict.  
 
3.  Much of Afghanistan’s road infrastructure was destroyed or damaged in more than two 
decades of conflict. Lack of resources and capacity prevented maintenance, and has led to 
major  deterioration  and  loss  of  infrastructure.  The  effects  of  military  actions  are  more 
pronounced in the form of damaged bridges and tunnels, which have become bottlenecks to the 
movement of people and goods. Restricted movement aggravates the country’s division and 
disintegration, as travel time and vehicle operating cost on roads have significantly increased.1 
  
4.  According to the comprehensive needs assessment on the Afghanistan transport sector, 
carried out during March-May 2002 by major external funding agencies including the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB), 54% of the national roads are in poor condition, 26% in fair condition, 
and only 20% in good condition. It urged the entire primary road network be rehabilitated on a 
priority basis.2 
 
5.  5.  Afghanistan’s road network is characterized by very low road density. The road 
density of 0.03 km per square km (km2) is far lower than that of Kyrgyz Republic and Tajikistan, 
which also have largely mountainous terrain and similar population densities, and even lower 
than 0.07 km/km2 road density of Balochistan in Pakistan, whose population density is about 
half of Afghanistan’s. Even without the damage inflicted during the conflict period, Afghanistan’s 
road network is in need of substantial improvement to provide basic connectivity that is available 
elsewhere in the subregion.

B.   Vehicle Fleet and Road Transport Industry 
 
6.  The number of vehicles has increased significantly over the past 2 years. According to 
statistics provided in a recent International Monetary Fund country report on Afghanistan,3 
transport of goods by road increased from 1.9 million tons in 2000 to 3.7 million tons in 2001 
and 5 million tons in 2002, representing an almost fourfold increase. Number of taxicabs nearly 
doubled from 17,000 in 2000 to 33,500 in 2002. More than 147,000 vehicles were estimated to 
be registered in Kabul, which under certain assumptions would translate into about 304,000 
vehicles countrywide. Most vehicles are owned and operated by the private sector.  
 
7.  The Ministry of Transport (MOT)-operated fleet has been severely depleted. According 
to the Central Statistical Office, in 2002 the Government owned and operated 22,459 vehicles 
consisting of 10,913 trucks (MOT: 210), 2,741 buses (MOT Millie buses: 230), and 8,162 cars, 
but nearly all these vehicles no longer exist. According to the Transport Sector Review, the 
centrally owned bus and lorry companies and also the trolley bus service have practically 
collapsed. MOT now has some of the Kamaz freight agencies and the Millie bus agency. MOT 
retains a trolley bus department, but no vehicles, workshops, or power supply network, which 
have all been destroyed. 
 
8.  The Afghan private sector has historically played a dominant role in trucking and has 
maintained its presence, including individuals and firms that relocated in Pakistan during the war 
years.  As  expected,  long  distance  public  transport,  linking  major  cities  and  neighboring 
countries, has deteriorated due to road and vehicle conditions as well as suppressed demand 
for road travel. Security remains a key concern. Urban transport is available, on a limited scale, 
in Kabul and provincial capitals. 
  
9.  Urban  transport,  once  dominated  by  the  public  sector,  is  now  mostly  provided  by 
privately owned buses, taxis, and minivans. Forms of regional transport depend on the state of 
the roads and the availability of vehicles. People and goods move together, blurring distinction 
between passenger and commercial freight traffic. Private agencies operate provincial and 
district routes. Some 165 registered long-distance private bus companies are estimated to be 
operating—101 based in Kabul, 64 in provinces—with a total of 14,007 buses, mostly old 
minibuses and vans. 
 
10.  The taxi system in Afghanistan is widespread and well organized. According to MOT, 24 
taxi  unions  registered  in  Kabul  and  27  in  the  provinces  have  a  total  of  29,131  vehicles.

C.   Road Administration 
 
11.  Road administration is highly centralized. Before the protracted hostilities, the Ministry of 
Public Works (MPW), through its 15 departments, was virtually responsible for all government 
construction and maintenance, including roads and bridges, airports, public housing, and water 
supply. All aspects of planning, design, construction, and maintenance were carried out in-
house  through  a  number  of  MPW  construction  units.  Before  1992,  just  one  of  MPW’s 
departments,  Road  Construction  and  Development,  had  more  than  5,000  employees.  In 
addition, MPW had a multitude of other responsibilities such as city planning, and collection of 
road tolls. Theoretically, MPW retains all of these responsibilities. The Ministry of Rehabilitation 
and Rural Development is responsible for development of rural infrastructure, including rural 
roads. Construction and maintenance of urban roads are the responsibility of municipalities. 
 
12.  Over the course of the conflict, the Government ministries lost a majority of their trained 
staff. In provinces where staff and equipment were retained, they were often under the influence 
of provincial governments and not fully under the control of the ministry headquarters in Kabul. 
This situation is gradually being realigned as the central Government successfully extends its 
control outside Kabul to provinces. The current staffing level of MPW is about 2,900, of which 
900 are employed on a permanent basis, 1,900 are paid daily wages, and 140 are military 
officers. Most of the current staff require substantial skills enhancement to perform their duties. 
 
13.  To fill the capacity gap, most of the externally funded projects are being implemented 
with assistance of international consultants in project management. Civil works are packaged 
into large contracts and bid out through competitive procedures to private sector contractors. 
Consultants engaged by MPW supervise the works of contractors. MPW is being transformed 
into  a  lean  and  thin  organization  with  its  primary  task  being  nationwide  policy  formation, 
planning of the countrywide road network, setting of standards (including technical, safety, 
social, and environmental safeguards), regulation and enforcement functions, and management 
of roads under its jurisdiction.

D.   Road Subsector Revenues and Expenditures 
 
14.  Currently, capital investment to rehabilitate and reconstruct roads in Afghanistan is 
mainly financed by external assistance. The current commitments to Afghanistan’s road 
subsector by the external bilateral/multilateral funding agencies amount to approximately $1 
billion, including $800 million for national primary roads, $130 million for national secondary 
roads, and $30 million for provincial roads. These commitments are mainly to rehabilitate 
damaged roads.  
 
15.  For the improvement of the road network, the Government has set a target to double 
the share of total paved roads from the present 16% to 32% by 2010, or from the present 
0.15 km of paved roads per 1,000 people to 0.23 km per 1,000 in 2010. To reach this target, 
the new investment needs from 2004 to 2010 will be for $4.3 billion outside the existing 
commitment: $1.7 billion for national primary roads, $1.1 billion for national secondary 
roads, and $1.5 billion for provincial roads.4 Considering the limited prospect for private 
sector financing of these large investments in the foreseeable future, the public sector will 
continue to be responsible for filling the financing gap.  
 
16.  Afghanistan has a history of toll collection for road maintenance. The first toll system 
was implemented in 1974. Tolls were collected by way of a system of toll stations scattered 
throughout the country, and the revenue was accrued to the central revenue fund with no 
earmarking for the road subsector. The allocations to the road subsector were by way of 
appropriations from the central revenue fund. A new system implemented in 1999 introduced 
earmarking  the  funds  for  construction  and  maintenance  of  highways.  MPW  organized  toll 
collection and the tolls were viewed as a source of MPW revenue. Through a decision by the 
High Council of Ministers on 23 September 2002, this road toll system was abolished. Private 
parties had established unauthorized toll collection stations in a number of locations, which 
created hardships for travelers without contributing to the maintenance program.  
 
17.  At present, fuel, spares, or vehicles area not taxed, except for customs duties. Some 
fees/levies are charged by the Ministry of Interior and Provincial Finance Department for vehicle 
registration and renewal.  
 
18.  The Government is in the process of establishing a tax regime. A few more years may 
be required to fully implement the new tax regime. In the meantime, imposing tolls, in particular 
on roads that have recently been rehabilitated, is viewed as an effective way to generate much-
needed revenue for road-related expenditure. Approximately $80 million is estimated to be 
required annually to maintain the entire road network. For a country with domestic revenues of 
$300 million, this will be a challenge. The Government is currently considering reinstating toll 
collection on improved road sections5 to cover the maintenance cost as well as to recover part 
of the capital investment cost.

POLICY STATEMENT FOR THE TRANSPORT SECTOR 1 
 
A.  Background and Purpose 
 
1.  The transport sector is one of the keys to the future development and well being of 
Afghanistan. The country’s mountainous features give rise to high transport costs, leave many 
communities profoundly isolated, and pose a challenge to nation building. Being land-locked 
adds to Afghanistan’s vulnerability. An efficient transport sector will not only reduce costs in 
comparison with the current situation; it is a pre-condition for strengthening the unity of the 
country, and promoting cohesion and the Afghan identity.  
 
2.  With this Policy Statement, the Transitional Islamic State of Afghanistan (TISA) wishes 
to chart a course for the development of the Afghan transport sector based on explicit policy 
formulations. The Statement represents the first policy document for the transport sector since 
the  Bonn  Agreement  in  December  2001,  and  supplements  the  National  Development 
Framework. It is viewed as an interim policy as the current administration is transitional; it is 
expected to be restated once the new administration in terms of the new constitution has come 
into power. Relevant provisions of the new constitution will be reflected in the restated Policy 
Statement  for  the  Transport  Sector.  The  restated  Statement  will  also  incorporate  relevant 
recommendations  from  the  Civil  Service  and  Privatization  Commissions,  accepted  by 
Government. These Commissions were still working on their recommendations at the time of 
preparing this Statement. 
 
3.  The need for a Policy Statement emanates from the condition that current legislation and 
institutional arrangements in the public sector have to a large extent been shaped during the 
period  of  occupation  when  foreign  powers  exerted  heavy  influence  on  policy  matters  in 
Afghanistan. The transport sector is hence characterized by heavy reliance on public ownership, 
centralization  and  archaic  organizational  arrangements  in  the  public  sector.  Production  of 
transport services is often in the hands of the public sector, and ministries are therefore not only 
engaged in determining policy but also, and more so, in operations and regulation. 
 
4.  The current arrangements do not promote efficiency and often also make it difficult to 
effectively address matters of public interest. The evidence may be seen all over the country: 
roads are not being maintained, transport services are of poor quality, the aviation safety 
system does not meet international standards, and road traffic safety is poor by any standards. 
This position is not only a result of the past conflicts and lack of funds; they also derive from 
inadequate policies and institutional arrangements. 
 
5.  The purposes of this Statement are: 
 
(i)  To formulate a long-term vision (10–15 years) for the overall development of the 
transport  sector;  the  realization  of  this  vision  assumes  peaceful  conditions 
prevailing in the country; and 
(ii)  To provide a framework for the identification of key actions required in the first 
phase for transforming the transport sector, encompassing the period up to the 
end of year 2008 (1387).

7.  The focus of this Statement is on the role and structure of government, the role of the

sector. 
 
8.  All modes of transport are covered. 
 
B.  The Basic Policy Objectives 
 
9.  The basic policy objectives of the Government are to: 
 
(i)  promote economic growth; 
(ii)  eradicate acute poverty; and 
(iii)  strengthen national unity. 
 
10.  To attain these objectives, resource utilization in the transport sector must be radically 
improved. This will have to be achieved whilst adequately addressing public interest issues such 
as: 
 
(i)  the provision of safe and secure transport services; 
(ii)  the protection of the environment; 
(iii)  the promotion of gender equality, attention to women needs in transport and 
participation of women in the sector; 
(iv)  the improvement in accessibility to rural and urban areas; and 
(v)  the promotion of competition. 
 
C.  The Means to Attain the Objectives 
 
11.  The main functions in the transport sector can be identified as follows: 
 
(i)  The supply of transport services, including intermediate services such as freight 
forwarding, clearing, and other agency services. 
(ii)  The provision and preservation of infrastructure. 
(iii)  The performance of regulatory activities to address public interest issues. 
(iv)  The performance of policy making and overall monitoring of sector development. 
 
12.  The Government’s view is that efficiency in the provision of transport services will best 
be attained by allowing competition and private sector participation. Transport services are, in 
general, best produced subject to the minimum of economic regulation with regard to entry, 
capacity and pricing. 
 
13.  The public sector has a much more central role in the provision of infrastructure on 
account of characteristics that cannot easily be handled by private interests, including high risks, 
network  effects  and  other  external  effects.  However,  the  Government  is  cognizant  of 
international experience in relation to arrangements for the planning, provision and operation of 
infrastructure that may significantly contribute to efficiency. These include:

(i)  The need for delegation of management to autonomous organizations within a 
governance framework providing for effective enforcement of accountability. 
(ii)  The importance of ensuring involvement by the users of infrastructure in the 
governance of the organizations charged with management. This may also entail 
decentralization of the management of infrastructure. 
(iii)  The importance of establishing self-financing mechanisms for the preservation, 
and also provision, of infrastructure facilities. 
(iv)  The need to engage contractors by competitive tendering procedures for the 
provision and preservation of infrastructure facilities 
 
14.  This notwithstanding, the Government recognizes that a market-based approach in the 
transport sector combined with autonomous management and self-financing of infrastructure 
facilities, whilst necessary, is not sufficient means to ensure a well-functioning transport sector. 
There are a number of public interest issues to be addressed as well, and these require 
regulation, which is a domain of the public sector. 
 
15.  The nature of the regulation required varies. Thus, some issues are not simply a concern 
of the transport sector, but cut across all sectors of the economy. For example certain aspects 
of environmental control relate to activities in other sectors as well. And the promotion of 
competition is a regulatory activity, which applies throughout the economy; it is therefore not 
considered further here. 
 
16.  Other issues are exclusive concerns of the transport sector, such as safety, security and 
the dimensions and environmental features of vehicles and aircraft. Regulatory activities in 
these areas essentially comprise the setting and enforcement of—or the provision of incentives 
to abide by—standards. Regulation is primarily directed towards individuals or companies. 
 
17.  With regard to accessibility and gender, regulation may include standard setting and 
enforcement, but the issues at hand may require a more pro-active role by the public sector. 
Accessibility is related to the provision of transport and infrastructure services at affordable 
prices to certain communities, which would be inadequately served by way of a purely market-
based approach. These communities, in addition, often tend to be poor and to live in very 
remote areas of the country or in inaccessible parts of urban areas. 
 
18.  The Government’s role with regard to accessibility is threefold: 
 
(i)  To formulate policies and establish standards with regard to accessibility. 
(ii)  To identify and establish an institutional framework which can effectively identify 
and put in place the means to implement policies and improve and achieve 
standards of accessibility. 
(iii)  To provide finance to ensure improved accessibility. 
 
19.  Regulatory  activities  with  regard  to  gender  normally  cut  across  all  sectors  in  the 
economy, for example measures to promote women careers in the public service. But there are 
also some transport sector dimensions to be noted: 
 
(i)  There are specific enforcement issues with regard to the use by women of taxis, 
buses and other means of transport, to ensure an equal treatment of both sexes. 
(ii)  There is a need to identify and develop transport solutions, which are responsive 
to the needs of women. An implication of this is that the organizations charged 
with the management of infrastructure and the provision of solutions for meeting

may  be  achieved  by  ensuring  women  representation  on  boards  in  agencies 
and/or incorporating appropriate instructions in planning and design manuals. 
 
20.  Since much regulation is of an operational nature, efficiency in performing regulatory 
functions can often be achieved by delegation to autonomous organizations, agencies, which 
perform their business within a transparent governance framework. This applies e.g. to the 
performance  of  regulatory  functions  to  promote  safety  and  security  in  transport  and

organizations are largely self-financing. It is the Government’s wish to promote the development 
of agencies of this nature. 
 
21.  Policy formulation, international relations, the drafting of legislation and sector monitoring 
are obvious functions for the public sector, and indeed the main functions to be performed by a 
ministry in the transport sector. 
 
D.  The Long-Term Vision for the Transport Sector 
 
22.  In terms of the overall objectives and the means identified to attain these objectives, and 
based on international experience, the Government has formulated the following vision for the 
transport sector. 
 
(i)  Transport  services:  Transport  operations  will  be  performed  by  private 
operators, subject to competition. This will apply to the provision of taxi, road 
haulage and bus transport, all intermediate services and air transport services. 
Subject to international agreements, competition is also expected to rule on 
international routes, including with respect to air transport, bus transport and road 
haulage. Transport operations will normally be provided without public subsidy. 
However,  certain  domestic  services  may  be  provided  under  public  service 
obligations, in order to ensure that minimum standards of accessibility in the 
country or urban areas are met. Such public service obligations will be procured 
by competitive tendering. 
(ii)  Roads:  The  national  road  network  will  have  been  rehabilitated,  and  where 
required, upgraded. It will be managed by an autonomous road agency, and its 
preservation and further development financed by road user charges, which are 
not part of the consolidated budget. Provincial and local roads will be managed 
by provincial and/or local road authorities, and a substantial part of their costs will 
also be financed by way of road user charges. A road fund will have been 
established to collect the road user charges and to serve as the procurer of road 
services from the road agency and local roads authorities, and hence to serve as 
the regulator of the road sector. Donor assistance will be directed towards the 
development of rural roads required to improve accessibility. Road works will 
mainly  be  done  by  contractors,  including  under  long-term  contracts  for 
maintenance.  A  substantial  amount  of  work  will  be  contracted  out  to  small 
contractors using labor-based techniques. 
(iii)  Airports and the air navigation system: The airports of the country will be 
managed by a number of airport companies. It is expected that these, with the 
exception of the airport in Kabul, will essentially have provincial ownership. The 
airports will be self-financing for their operations (but not necessarily for their 
development). The air navigation system (ANS) will be operated by a separate 
corporate  self-financing  entity;  it  will  also  operate  the  ANS  at  the  airports.

Legislation  establishing  the  airports  and  ANS  corporations  will  enable  the 
facilities  and  services  to  be  privately  financed  and  operated  in  terms  of  a 
concession. A system for economic regulation, comprising mainly self-regulatory 
arrangements, with regard to the airports and ANS will have been established. 
(iv)  Safety: A new agency for the regulation of safety, security and environmental 
protection in aviation will have been established. Similarly, the regulation of road 
traffic with regard to safety and environmental aspects specific to the road sector 
will have been entrusted to another agency, also expected to handle registration 
of licenses and vehicles. Both as concerns aviation and road traffic, Afghanistan 
will regulate safety and security adequately in terms of internationally accepted 
standards. 
(v)  Railways and rivers: Investments in river transport facilities and railways will be 
encouraged.  River  and  railway  transport  developments  will  essentially  be  a 
responsibility  of  the  private  sector.  The  government  may  participate  in  such 
developments provided that demonstrated economic benefits may be derived 
therefrom, which cannot be captured by private investors, or in order to improve 
accessibility to remote regions in a cost-effective manner. 
(vi)  Organization  of  government  in  transport:  A  new  ministry  will  have  been 
established, to replace the current three ministries in the transport sector, i.e. 
Ministry of Transport, Ministry of Civil Aviation and Tourism and the Ministry of 
Public Works (MPW), and will be charged with policy work for the road sector, 
road transport, multi-modal transport, air transport, and new modes, such as rail 
and river transport. This new ministry will ultimately also be responsible for road 
traffic (except enforcement), an area which today partly falls under the Ministry of 
Interior, as well as policy matters related to rural roads, which are today handled 
by the Ministry of Rural Rehabilitation and Development. The new ministry will 
additionally have become responsible for international relations and for preparing 
the public budget in the sector. The ministry will have a staff of a couple of 
hundred  persons.  To  ensure  accountability  of  the  new  agencies  and 
corporations, an explicit governance regime will have been put in place. The 
governance regime will encompass objectives for these organizations that may 
be measured, the publication of periodic and annual reports to shed light on the 
attainment of the objectives, and arrangements to allow for the involvement of 
users and other stakeholders. The day-to-day monitoring of these organizations 
will normally be performed by the new ministry in the transport sector. 
 
E.  Short-Term Conditions 
 
23.  The  vision  formulated  above  is  ambitious;  it  will  be  a  challenge  to  Afghanistan  to 
restructure the transport sector accordingly, but to ensure the well being of its citizen’s attempts 
must be made. In the short run perspective it is important to embark on a process of change 
that will eventually lead towards the realization of the vision. 
 
24.  In the short-term, the Government has decided to also take the following considerations 
into account: 
 
(i)  Privatization is not possible in the near future of the national carrier, Ariana, as it 
is loss making. Similarly, in the near future it will not be possible to privatize the 
Ministry of Transport road haulage and bus transport operations, as the country 
has received and is receiving a substantial number of donated vehicles. These 
operations should, however, be commercialized, as a first step towards later 
privatization.

(ii)  In international air transport operation there will be a need to offer protection to 
Ariana for a period of time. There are two reasons, viz. the need to ensure 
international connectivity given that the aviation safety and security system in 
Afghanistan  has  not  been  ICAO  certified,  and  the  modalities  with  regard  to 
international aviation in the region. Ariana is, however, expected to be profitable 
and only to serve routes not expected to be loss making in a medium term 
perspective.  Also,  the  small  domestic  market,  in  part  on  account  of  the 
inadequate facilities at present, does not lend itself to open competition for the 
time being, but may provide scope for a regulated system designed to encourage 
the participation of the private sector. However, air cargo may be liberalized. 
(iii)  The country at present does not have an established corps of contractors. Whilst 
construction works, and large maintenance contracts may be handled by way of 
international contractors, local contractors can for some time only be expected to 
handle part of the maintenance works. There will therefore be a need for the 
MPW to maintain limited force account capacity for the time being to perform 
(routine)  road  maintenance  and  also  to  undertake  emergency  repairs  to 
supplement the capacity of the private sector. 
(iv)  The current administrative weakness of the provinces implies that decentralized 
solutions as concerns e.g. airports and road sector management will have to be 
delayed for some time. 
(v)  For the time being, the financing arrangements in the road sector are subject to 
agreement  reached  by  the  TISA  with  the  World  Bank  concerning  the 
implementation of the Emergency Transport Rehabilitation Project. 
(vi)  Fundamental restructuring of the ministries is not possible at present. However, 
partial restructuring in terms of the Decree on Priority Reform and Restructuring 
within  Ministries  may  be  effected.  This  Decree  allows  for  departments  of 
ministries to be given priority reform and restructuring (PRR) status, so that 
individuals appointed to key posts in these departments may be offered better 
conditions on a time-limited basis and subject to performance. In addition, in the 
near future the functions related to (i) vehicle registration and drivers’ licensing 
should be transferred from the Ministry of Interior to the Ministry of Transport, (ii) 
airport airside infrastructure should be transferred from the Ministry of Public 
Works to the Ministry of Civil Aviation and Tourism, and (iii) rural roads from the 
Ministry of Rural Rehabilitation and Development to the Ministry of Public Works. 
 
F.  Short-Term Actions 
 
25.  Based on the above considerations, a number of short term actions—in order to initiate 
reform  of  the  transport  sector—will  be  proposed  by  the  Transport  Sector  Review  for 
implementation during the period up to the end of 2008; see the Action Plan of the Transport 
Sector Review.

developing  the  transport  sector.  The  Government’s  view  is  that  a  key  to  trigger  this 
development, but also to ensure a balanced approach with adequate attention paid to the public 
interest issues, is building the capacity of the public sector. The challenge is formidable in view 
of the shortage of skills and the fact that the ministries until recently were steeped in a culture 
inappropriate to the future needs. To be able to move forward, the existing ministries will have to 
be used as a platform to implement change and reform.

The Andkhoy-Qaisar road is one of the last unpaved sections of the national primary ring road, which circles

B.  Poverty Analysis                                 Targeting Classification: General intervention           
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
 
About 53% of the population in Afghanistan are classified as poor and live on less than $1 a day.1 The prolonged war 
in the country exacerbated by drought has severely affected the livelihoods of the local population. Decreased farm 
productivity and loss of seasonal opportunities for agricultural labor is one of the main determinants of poverty. The 
present state of infrastructure, especially roads, is a severe constraint in the revival of food security, livelihood 
opportunities, provision of and accessibility to social and economic services, and overall economic growth. An 
estimate of poverty incidence through proxy measures in the project influence area indicates that about 35–50% 
households are poor, and among the poor households 50–80% are living in absolute poverty. The average monthly 
income of the poor households is as low as AF3,700 with the very poor households being more concentrated in 
Faryab province. Most villages in the project influence area lack primary health care facilities or they are located at 
least 10 kilometers (km) away from basic health care clinics. Due to absence of primary health care facilities coupled 
with poor condition of roads and lack of transportation facilities, the mortality rate was observed to be high among 
women and children from simple complications of childbirth, lack of proper immunization, and preventable childhood 
illness. Afghanistan ranks 4th highest for the under-5 mortality rate at 257 deaths /1,000 and the infant mortality rate is 
at a high 165/1000.2  
 
The direct poverty impact would be from income generation and demand for unskilled labor resulting directly from road 
construction. The estimated cost of unskilled labor for constructing the project road is 6% of the total civil works, and 
the wages accruing to unskilled labor is calculated as AF10 million. The improved road will significantly reduce 
transport cost and travel time. This will translate into improved access to schools, medical clinics, and employment 
centers. Further, the improved road would decrease the chances of accident deaths and disabilities that have resulted 
from extremely poor road conditions. The poverty impact ratio (0.69) indicates that the poor will receive a high 
proportion of these benefits. The indirect, but important impact will be the growth of local trade, production activities, 
and reduced prices of commodities facilitated by improved access to local, national, and international markets. The 
road improvement is also expected to mainstream local economies with the overall national economy, and facilitate 
exploitation of available natural resources, such as minerals, gas, and other resources. These benefits are expected to 
significantly increase household incomes and quality of life, and reduce the overall poverty incidence.

E.  Distribution Analysis 
 
13.  A  study  on  transport  industry  was  conducted  for  the  Kabul-Kandahar  section.  The 
following is the assessment based on this study. A follow-up study is currently being undertaken 
and the assessment will be updated with use of the follow-up study. 
 
14.  Regarding competition among individual firms in the freight sector, a significant degree 
of competition is available for the hauling business. Research indicates that a significant drop in 
freight rates was realized for World Food Program freight over 6 months. The freight forwarding 
company takes a percentage (5–10%) of the contract price, passing the rest on to the driver.  
 
15.  In the passenger transport sector, competition is relatively less. Bus drivers pay a fee to 
the cooperative for one passenger fare for the larger buses and 60% of one fare for taxi and 
smaller buses. It was not clear whether this requirement was enforced by the Ministry of 
Transport or by the leadership of the cooperative and whether the collectives have records of 
the accounts. A fixed rotation system is used; the driver is given a number and must wait for all 
of the drivers holding prior numbers to get a load of passengers before he becomes eligible for 
a trip. This fixed rotation prevents individual operators from competing with one another on 
either price or service. Because of this limit to competition, price of passenger transport could 
be held above the open competition price. The Ministry of Transport also intervenes in this 
market by setting an official passenger tariff. Normally passenger transporters must pay 0.2% of 
their combined passenger fares at their first Ministry of Transport fee collection. However, tariff 
collection is not very standardized, which is an important weakness in the system. 
 
16.  Based on the assessment of the project area, the poverty impact ratio for the overall 
Project is estimated to be 0.69. This high level indicates that the poor will receive a high 
proportion of benefits. Detailed analysis is in Supplementary Appendix A.

SUMMARY INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The Project is categorized as a “B” Project in accordance with the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) Guidelines on Environmental Assessment. An initial environmental examination 
(IEE) was prepared. This appendix is based on the information in the IEE and summary IEE 
reports undertaken under the project preparatory technical assistance1 on behalf of the Ministry 
of Public Works.  
 
B.  Description of the Project 
 
2.  The Andkhoy-Qaisar road is a segment of the ring road, which connects the major cities 
of Afghanistan. The Project will involve (i) reconstruction and improvement of a 210 kilometer 
(km) road section; (ii) improvement of about 10 river crossings on the 210 km stretch; and (iii) 
provision of markings, signs, and other safety features. The improvement and reconstruction of 
the road aims to achieve a design standard with the following typical cross section: (i) in flat and 
rolling terrain:, two traffic lanes each 3.5 meters (m) wide, with two hard shoulders each 1.5 m 
wide each, and two verges 0.5 m wide, with a total width of 11.0 m; and (ii) in mountainous 
terrain: the same traffic lanes with hard shoulders reduced to 0.5 m, with a total width of 8.0 m. 
  
C.  Description of the Environment 
 
3.  The Project is administratively located within Faryab. The environmental condition of the 
project area along the road is briefly summarized here. 
 
1.  Physical Environment 
 
4.  The road passes through different topography from north to southwest. From Andkhoy to 
Daulatabad (61 km), the terrain is an open plain with gentle slope. The elevation of this area 
ranges from 320 to 400 m above sea level. The open plain continues along the Shirin Tagab 
River up to a point 113 km away from Andkhoy, at an elevation of 750 m. Thereafter a short 
section of hilly terrain continues to Maimana (129 km from Andkhoy at an elevation of 866 m). 
After Maimana, the terrain becomes gentle and elevations stay between 840 and 940 m except 
the last 23 km to Qaisar. After Qaisar (187 km from Andkhoy at an elevation of 1,340 m), the 
project road runs along the Qaisar River and ends at a point before a small settlement called 
Khazara Qala (210 km from Andkhoy) in Qaisar District.  
 
2.  Ecological Environment 
 
5.  Only 4% of Afghanistan is forested, mostly in the east and southeast. The deciduous 
forests have almost completely disappeared, as have almost 95% of the juniper forests. The 
vegetation along the corridor of the project road is primarily semidesert, which mainly consists of 
resistant grasses, various shrubs such as tamarisk, and sand acacia. The irrigated areas are 
mostly planted with grains, wheat, and other crops. Orchards and vineyards are common in the

6.  With regard to the fauna in the project area, several domestic animals such as camels,

D.  Screening of Potential Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures 
 
7.  The environmental impacts associated with the construction stage include (i) disruption 
of traffic in the construction area, (ii) increased air pollution due to increasing dust and other 
volatile chemical substances from the asphalt plant, (iii) noise and vibration, (iv) disruption of the 
water system due to construction of bridges and other earth work particularly in the valley areas, 
and (v) potential landslides associated with elevating some part of the road. These impacts will 
all occur only during the construction period. Mitigation measures to minimize these impacts 
include (i) rerouting traffic with clear signs; (ii) maintaining optimum moisture content during soil 
handling, spraying water to minimize dust, and maintaining a safe distance between the asphalt 
plant and public facilities including education facilities; (iii) strictly controlling construction works 
that create noise and vibration by prohibiting night work in residential areas; (iv) locating the hot-
mix and crusher plants at least 1 km from residential areas; (v) pumping stagnant water, and 
providing adequate drainage system; and (vi) stabilizing road embankment side slopes. These 
measures will be included in the contract document for the civil works. These impacts are all 
temporary and manageable. 
 
8.  Camps for construction works will be established in areas that are not prone to social 
conflicts. The camps will need to be complete with adequate sanitation facilities and waste 
management  to  avoid  disturbance  to  the  communities.  Construction  materials  that  contain 
hazardous and toxic substances such as petroleum, and asphalt should be stored in proper 
places and managed in accordance with the relevant international standards.   
 
9.  The environmental impact associated with the operation of the Project is mainly on traffic 
safety, therefore, adequate traffic signs and physical barriers to reduce motorist speed must be 
provided . This measure needs to be strictly enforced particularly in villages and towns along the 
road corridor, where markets usually take place.  
  
E.  Institutional Requirement and Environmental Monitoring Program 
 
10.  Institutional Framework and Responsibility. Implementation of mitigation measures 
during construction will be the responsibility of the contractor. An environmental engineer, who 
will be hired as part of the consultant team to implement the Project, will help the Ministry of 
Public Work (MPW) prepare contractual documentation so that the bidding documents, bills of 
quantity,  and  other  contractual  obligations  of  the  contractor  clearly  identify  environmental 
responsibilities  and  describe  penalties  for  noncompliance.  MPW  will  be  responsible  for 
implementing overall environmental monitoring and management as part of the IEE. 
 
11.  Environmental  Monitoring  and  Management  Plan.  The IEE identified the generic 
monitoring and management program, which will be part of mitigating adverse impacts. Annual 
reports in implementing the monitoring and management plan will be submitted to ADB and 
other relevant Government agencies.

56 Appendix 13 
F.  Findings and Recommendations 
 
12.  The  IEE  study  shows  that  environmental  impacts  associated  with  the  Project  are 
manageable and can be mitigated. Therefore, a full environmental impact assessment to assess 
further impacts of roads involved in this Project is not required.  
 
G.   Public Consultation and Information Disclosure 
 
13.  Public consultation during the preparation of the IEE was done in a very informal manner 
with the population living along the road project. In general, consulted communities did not show 
any objection to the proposed improvement, and did not have any particular concerns about the 
potential  impacts  associated  with  the  Project.  Therefore,  MPW  should  carry  out  a  public 
consultation during project implementation, particularly prior to the start of the construction. 
 
H.   Conclusion 
 
14.  The Project will improve existing roads. The overall IEE finding is that the Project will not 
cause  significant  environmental  problems  and  potential  adverse  impacts  are  manageable. 
However, continued monitoring should be carried out.
